page.title: 01North Yorkshire Moors
page.content: The centre of the North Yorkshre moors 410 metres above sea level. Open peat moorland exists on ridge tops with small farms in the valleys. The former is covered with heather and braken and latter consist of small fields. Bounded by dry stone walling. Some deciduous trees exist in the valley areas alongside streams. Roads are narrow and tarmaced. Several public footpaths cross the area. Twenty dwellings exist constructed of rectangualr stone blocks. Cattle are fed in valleys, paint marked sheep roam the moorland freely. Predominant wild fauna/flora are grouse, pheasants and hawks with a prolific display of daffodils in spring. Weather sometimes bleak and windy, the area being occasionally cut off during
